Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story:
I glanced at the maintenance schedule pinned to the workshop wall, my name circled in red for next week’s planned shutdown. As the senior machine repairer, everyone expected me to lead the routine servicing—cleaning, oiling, and checking every bolt to keep the machines running smoothly. The shutdown was rare, and missing it could mean weeks of breakdowns and complaints. My supervisor had already reminded me twice: “We need you here, no excuses.”

But at home, my mother was busy preparing for the family ceremony. Next week was the festival, and as a Hindu, I was expected to be there—on time, dressed in my best, ready to join the prayers and rituals. My father’s voice echoed in my mind: “Family comes first, especially during the festival. Don’t let us down.”

The two calendars—one at work, one at home—clashed in my mind. I felt the pressure building, torn between the whirring machines that depended on my hands and the sacred traditions that shaped my heart. I sat on my bed, staring at my uniform and my festival clothes, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which path I would choose.
